subject: BaseBiosTable: Add support for PATCH operation
commitMessage:
BaseBiosTable: Add support for PATCH operation

This commit brings in support for PATCH operation of the
bios variables that updates the BaseBiosTable.

Tested-By:
* Passed Redfish validator

* Single/Multiple Attributes:
PATCH https://${bmc}/redfish/v1/Systems/system/Bios/Settings -d
'{"Attributes":{<attribute name_1>:<attribute value_1>, ... ,
<attribute name_n>:<attribute value_n>}}'

This makes use of the "Set" of "PendingAttributes" in the
backend and that updates the BaseBiosTable.

Change-Id: I2f4fbd57bc18316bb213b54c32b472719ab44cc0
Signed-off-by: Asmitha Karunanithi <asmitk01@in.ibm.com>
Signed-off-by: Kuiying Wang <kuiying.wang@intel.com>

Abandoned

No responses from submitters or people working on the prereq for this patch.  Please reopen if this is still being actively pursued

Did you test with patching multiple attributes in single shot ?
Did this pass the Validator ?
Same as https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/bmcweb/+/38702/2/redfish-core/lib/bios.hpp#303
Still would like to see the validator in the tested section.

I find that the validator fails against the base commit by Kwin.

But I will check and update the commit message!

As far as i understood, patch should be supported on Setting object right ? should it not come under `/redfish/v1/Systems/system/Bios/Settings` ?

Correct me if i am wrong.
Ack
redundant code ? can we use already existing functions ?

Do we have these functions?
I would suggest we should create a new function as line no 64.

> redundant code ? can we use already existing functions ?

We have a method `mapAttrTypeToRedfish` line 64, that maps the attribute type (xyz.openbmc_project.BIOSConfig.Manager.AttributeType.*) to corresponding type but not vice versa.

> I would suggest we should create a new function as line no 64.

Sure, this can be taken to a method if this will be used in more than one place.
But now, it is used only here. Hence, I put it this way!
Pending attributes is a vector that can hold mutiple attributes at a time..does the existing logic supports it ?

the existing logic has no support for multiple attributes in one shot.
But this needs further testing.

I will check on it.
emplace_back is better in this scenario.
Ack

Do we need to use the setattribute function?
https://github.com/openbmc/phosphor-dbus-interfaces/blob/master/xyz/openbmc_project/BIOSConfig/Manager.interface.yaml#L8
is this function call needed ?
Oops. Have missed removing this!
better naming ?
Ack

Run redfish validator.

Set will not have direct impact on validator but subsequent get will have. So set some attributes and run redfish validator.
This should be "ConfigureComponents" as per Privilege Registry. https://redfish.dmtf.org/registries/Redfish_1.1.0_PrivilegeRegistry.json
-1: This logic is wrong.  You should not use "else if" here.

No need of else.

1) Read all 3 attributes( Name, Type, Value) - No else if
2) Create tuple and Call d-bus(Line: 453)
No point in looping through other array objects during failure  case. Return as soon as its fails Line no: 416, 421, 426.

Its requires its own message entry to convey the actual failure.

That message registry entry can take Attribute Name and Type. So that user should know which array element is wrong.
Need to update the commit message also, data would be replaced with Attributes.

data is not in the schema? should it be Attributes?
https://redfish.dmtf.org/schemas/v1/Bios.v1_1_1.json

It is not there in the schema.If I look at the commit https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/bmcweb/+/29670/50 
We return the attributes as eg:
   "Attributes": {
        "attr0": "current value"
    },
Hence AttributeName,AttributeType,AttributeValue will not be there as keys..

Request should look like as 
PATCH https://${bmc}/redfish/v1/Systems/system/Bios/Settings -d
'{"Attributes":[{"attr0":"value0"},{"attr1":"value1"}]}'
by reference?
Since we are just reading the attributes json and not modyfying, do we really need to capture it by ref?
It is not a property missing, It is kind of invalid value.
Ack
Invalid value..Do we have some other redfish error which can specify which value in the array?

you mean to say, "value at this position is invalid"?

If so, i hope there's no redfish error message for the same.
I think we can have invalidObject("Attributes").

Your thoughts, Ratan?
This type is only used in one place.  Please inline into the scope it's used.
flat-map is not requried here, as the key lookup is never used.  Please use std::vector<std::pair< instead.
The key look up is being used in line no. 423
Ack
string copy.  Please avoid.
Ack
String copy, please avoid.
Ack

Please use emplace here here, and construct in place.  Example of constructing a std::pair in place here:
https://stackoverflow.com/questions/55831362/construct-stdpair-in-place-in-vectoremplace-back
Ack
attrName not being allowed to be empty makes sense, but that validation should be handled in the bios daemon.  attrValue can be empty though, right?
(Only attribute name check can be done here and the validation should be left to the backend) - Ack
Reading again, why is either check required?
I missed this in PS10. Have updated it in the latest PS (11)

Can this be done at the upper level scope?  Nothing in this loop requires anything from the callback return, so I suspect it can be moved up, and we can simply capture pendingAttributes, instead of capturing the entire json object in the lambda.

Sorry, Ed. Am not getting it here.

We have the first lambda - to get the base bios table, where we populate the map with attributes name and their types.

Once done, keys in the attrsJson would be looked up in the map to get their corresponding types which would then be emplaced back to pendingAttributes obj. So, this requires attrsJson to be captured in this lambda. Do you see that I am missing something here?

Ah, I missed part of that in my reading.  Why does the BIOS API require two calls to set an attribute and lookup the type?  Shouldn't we already know the type from the json, and can't the API itself be typeless?  Can it be simplified to only require one?

This kind of API (check some attribute to build request) is somewhat an anti-pattern, and complicates the API.

> Why does the BIOS API require two calls to set an attribute and lookup the type?
>and can't the API itself be typeless?
I think the patchset 10 has created a confusion. The API now is typeless. (My latest PS 11 changes) So I am having two calls i) to populate the map of attr names to their types; ii) set the pending attributes
Why do we need to populate a map at all?  Why can't we just call set directly?

The backend dbus call to set the pending attributes has the signature a{s(sv)}.
It calls for {attribute name => attribute type and value}. So to get the attribute type, the idea was, if we have a map of all the attribute names and its corresponding types, we could directly get it from there.

That sounds like a dbus api that needs reworked.  Having a type implicit in the set call requires exactly this code you've written, which is quite complex and error prone.  Normally an API like this would simply enumerate the various properties, with the appropriate types as properties individually, not as one super dictionary, especially not as a super dictionary that ignored the dbus typing system.

Alternatively, you could add a "AddPendingChange" method which takes a key and value pair, and puts this complexity into the bios manager daemon.

It should also be noted that looking at this API, there's no way to add pending attributes without effecting the previously added pending attributes.  That seems like an issue.

As written, I don't want to be doing two calls for this type of operation.  It adds code and imposes extra conditions in Redfish, which should be a simple json->dbus call converter.

> Alternatively, you could add a "AddPendingChange" method which takes a key and value pair, and puts this complexity into the bios manager daemon.

Agree.
@Ratan Do you have any thoughts here?


> It should also be noted that looking at this API, there's no way to add pending attributes without effecting the previously added pending attributes.  That seems like an issue.

Yes, Ed. This would override the previous values in the pending attributes and then get pushed to the Bios table.


> As written, I don't want to be doing two calls for this type of operation.  It adds code and imposes extra conditions in Redfish, which should be a simple json->dbus call converter.

Ack.

> Alternatively, you could add a "AddPendingChange" method which takes a key and value pair, and puts this complexity into the bios manager daemon.

Ed, We already have the following API in the Dbus Backend.
https://github.com/openbmc/bios-settings-mgr/blob/master/src/manager.cpp#L33

But with this Dbus API we have to make multiple D-bus calls for multiple properties. 

Are you fine to have multiple D-bus calls for patching of multiple BIOS attributes?

Or

Are you suggesting that we should have setAttributes which have the following signature.

void Manager::setAttributes(std::vector<AttributeName , AttributeValue>) -> with this API caller doesn't bother about the type checking and multiple attributes can be set in one D-bus call.

> It should also be noted that looking at this API, there's no way to add pending attributes without effecting the previously added pending attributes.  That seems like an issue

No, This is not an issue as during changing of the pending attributes properties, it changes the value of the existing BIOS attribute if exist otherwise it adds the BIOS attribute which is not there in the pending attributes.

https://github.com/openbmc/bios-settings-mgr/blob/master/src/manager.cpp#L282

"Are you fine to have multiple D-bus calls for patching of multiple BIOS attributes?"

Simply put, no, as it makes this code very complex and have possible race conditions.


"void Manager::setAttributes(std::vector<AttributeName , AttributeValue>) -> with this API caller doesn't bother about the type checking and multiple attributes can be set in one D-bus call."

I'm making some assumptions, as the type you put above isn't really valid.  I'm assuming you means std::vector<std::pair<std::string, std::string>>.  That type would probably prevent updates of individual parameters, so that API doesn't look quite right either.  I would assume a single set version would be the right way to approach this, something similar to SetProperty, but accepting a string type that the backend could properly turn into the correct type.

> I would assume a single set version would be the right way to approach this, something similar to SetProperty, but accepting a string type that the backend could properly turn into the correct type.

That suggest you are looking for this API..
https://github.com/openbmc/phosphor-dbus-interfaces/blob/master/xyz/openbmc_project/BIOSConfig/Manager.interface.yaml#L8

If it is then I don't see what has to be reworked on the dbus backend.?

> > I would assume a single set version would be the right way to approach this, something similar to SetProperty, but accepting a string type that the backend could properly turn into the correct type.
> 
> That suggest you are looking for this API..
> https://github.com/openbmc/phosphor-dbus-interfaces/blob/master/xyz/openbmc_project/BIOSConfig/Manager.interface.yaml#L8
> 
> If it is then I don't see what has to be reworked on the dbus backend.?

This patchset is still doing 2 calls instead of one.  I haven't looked the abovedbus  interface, but JUST looking at this commit I would assume that:
1. The interface doesn't support setting params as a single step.
2. The interface changes weren't made in this patchset.

Requirement: How to do patching of multiple BIOS attributes from the bmcweb?

Dbus interface: https://github.com/openbmc/phosphor-dbus-interfaces/blob/master/xyz/openbmc_project/BIOSConfig/Manager.interface.yaml

BIOS config doc: https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/docs/+/29320/18/designs/remoteBIOSConfiguration.md

To support the above requirement we have two choices with the current Dbus interfaces

1) Either do multiple Dbus calls by using this API.
https://github.com/openbmc/phosphor-dbus-interfaces/blob/master/xyz/openbmc_project/BIOSConfig/Manager.interface.yaml#L8

cons: Multiple Dbus calls for each BIOS attribute.
 

2) Do a single Dbus call by updating the following property 
https://github.com/openbmc/phosphor-dbus-interfaces/blob/master/xyz/openbmc_project/BIOSConfig/Manager.interface.yaml#L105

Cons:  2 D-bus calls (1 for getting the BaseBiosTable property and 1 for updating the pending attributes)


As per your comments above you don't like either option 1) or option 2).

What is your view?
